Affirmation and Stereotype Threat

October 31st, 2014

confidence - 4
friendships - 4
inspiration - 4
meaningful work - 3
personal development - 4
cooperation - 2
responsibility - 3
faith - 5
helping in society - 3
persistence - 3

Values and morals are important foundations for our perspectives and actions. They are what influence what we see and consequently, we act upon our views. I often remind myself that these values and morals must be my grounding despite how busy life gets and no matter how much I want to accomplish. Because without them, thoughts and actions go unchecked. Sooner or later, nothing will be as meaningful if what I've become on the inside has spoiled.

I can't say that I live up to each value to the fullest extent everyday, but I definitely try my best to and plan on extending that effort into DBC. Since DBC emphasizes the importance of pair programming and team work, I look forward to building relationships with others in a supportive environment. Being in an open and supportive environment has always enabled me to try harder in fulfilling my responsibilities and helping others whenever and however possible. I feel more accomplished when I contribute something into group work because the work and relationships become more meaningful.

As I mentioned in my stereotype threat post, focusing on myself and others as individuals, I believe, will enable me to handle stereotype threats. These values are the important things to focus on with an individual and I believe we should value others for their values.
